article.title: Effects of Space Flight on Mouse Liver versus Kidney: Gene Pathway Analyses
funding: NASA Grants NNX13AN32G, NNX12AM93G, and NNX10AP01G
article.abstract: Understanding genome wide, tissue-specific, and spaceflight-induced changes in gene expression is critical to develop effective countermeasures.

sections.introduction: Transcriptome and proteasome analysis has been performed on diverse tissues harvested from several animal species flown in space.
sections.methods: Working in collaboration with NASA Ames Research Center and Bioserve Space Technologies, female C57BL/6J mice were housed in the animal enclosure module (AEM) with special food bars, redundant lixit water supply, and a waste management system.
sections.results: Liver and kidney tissues showed similar gene response to spaceflight.
sections.discussion: By analyzing the transcriptome of liver and kidney from animals flown in space versus ground control animals, we were able to evaluate the extent to which tissues from different organs respond to spaceflight in shared ways versus organ-specific ways.

article.insights_summary: Liver and kidney show both tissue-specific and shared tissue-common responses to the stress of spaceflight.
article.acknowledgments: We thank the Medical College of Georgia for performing gene arrays.
